My thoughts are along the lines of this extracted 'nugget'... "While economic downturns are usually credit-induced, the COVID-19 slowdown was caused by the shutdown of the economy and it forced incomes to fall, said Daniel Booth, CIO of the £45 billion ($56.4 billion) Border to Coast Pensions Partnership, Leeds, England, a pool of U.K. local authority pension funds. Therefore, rates are less efficient as tools to help with the recovery, he added. Instead, central banks are financing deficits to stimulate the economy, which at some stage causes inflation, he said.On the other hand, lower gross domestic product forecasts foreshadow lower inflation in 2020." The way the inflation is computed matters a lot here. The figure will be the ratio vs the CPI a year ago, which was particularly high in june 19. As a consequence, we will "observe" a very low number, possibly negative, even if the prices remain flat versus the month of May. 
My guess: CPI flat vs May, means 0.1% decrease. Thus more weight on negative than positive. I don't see much signs of increasing prices or strong decreases compared to last month: covid situation is stabilizing and markets opening again. That adds a bit of chance to an increase. Final choice a 55-55 instead of a 60-40. No strong rational for the %. I think we are going to be very close to the border of the two answers.

Cool article from FAZ last week (one of the most reputable newssources in Germany). Bank Sarasin expects -0.2 % for June (although that might be a little too pessimistic…). https://www.faz.net/aktuell/wirtschaft/in-12-von-19-eurostaaten-ist-die-inflation-jetzt-negativ-16819418.html Only one week to go.

Over exposed in .1 basket.  Energy prices have picked up significantly, however much of the eurozone pays higher fees due to renewables anyway, and so are insulated. ECB funds to buy bonds will add a tiny bounce. It looks as if the minimum will come exactly on schedule followed by a rebound.  I give actual odds at 55:45 that it goes neg

While the countries have opened up and energy prices picked up slightly I still think the downward trend is too hard to ignore. I am moving from 50/50 to 80/20 https://m.faz.net/aktuell/wirtschaft/in-12-von-19-eurostaaten-ist-die-inflation-jetzt-negativ-16819418.html

Evolution since pandemic began (february onwards): 1.2, 0.7, 0.3, 0.1, which suggest that we should at least be at 0.0 or less for June. Four probable values that come to mind are: 0.1 , 0.0, -0.1, -0.2. By bucketing then I would assign a 25% probability for 0.1 or more. Average inflation expected this year is somewhere between 0.2-0.3%, which a probable negative spike right now. Just from assuming that from June onwards the inflation is going to be constant, we require from -0.2 to 0.0% on average on what is left of the year. From this I further reduce (rather arbitrarily though) from 25 to 15% for the +0.1% bucket.

[Broadly speaking] projections suggest "no less than 0%," given government (world-wide) stimulus packages and Covid restrictions, generally, loosening...  *I consider a significant flaw in my proposal is the possibility of a 'lag-time in figures reported/published' vs 'real-time data.'  https://www.ecb.europa.eu/pub/projections/html/index.en.html#:~:text=The%20projections%20foresee%20annual%20HICP,in%202021%20and%202022%2C%20respectively.&text=The%20projections%20foresee%20real%20GDP,and%20by%203.3%25%20in%202022.

The annual rate of inflation since Jan 20 has been 1.4, 1.2, 0.7, 0.3, 0.1 (measured monthly). The trend shows only one direction.  But Europe has been slowly opening up over June. That could keep inflation in the 0.1% to 1.0% zone (obviously nearer to the lower end of that band). On the other hand measuring lags could ensure that the trend stays and goes negative before improving. The 19 country Inflation rate has been negative in 2015/16 and in 2009.  So I am going overweight on the 0.0% or less bucket (70% from 40%)
And underweight on the 0.1% to 1.0% bucket (30% from 60%)

On the basis of current and futures prices for oil, headline inflation is likely to decline somewhat further over the coming months and to remain subdued until the end of the year. Over the medium term, weaker demand will put downward pressure on inflation, which will be only partially offset by upward pressures related to supply constraints. Market-based indicators of longer-term inflation expectations have remained at depressed levels. While survey-based indicators of inflation expectations have declined over the short and medium term, longer-term expectations have been less affected."

Re-base rating this question based on the trend.

The European Commission Spring 2020 forecast, released May 6, predicts 2020 annual inflation at 0.2% for the Euro Area [1]. Ten of the nineteen Euro Area countries saw negative inflation in April, so it is definitely possible. Germany, the largest economy,  was at 0.9% in April, but I'd expect that to drop in the coming months due to the delayed impacts of the virus there as compared to Italy, Spain, etc. Is the calculation for the Euro Area simply weighted by the country's GDP or is it done in some other way? I couldn't find a helpful answer. The only forecasts for June that I could find were from Trading Economics which forecasts 0.1% [2].  The conclusion I draw from all this is that it's going to be pretty close to zero and may go below. I think there's a probability that supply shortages could spike food or other prices, though I don't think this would be enough to offset all other factors and surpass 1%. [1] https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_799
[2] https://tradingeconomics.com/euro-area/inflation-cpi

Revising: Every time inflation has been this low, it's gone below zero. I don't think it'll go below zero because it doesn't seem like fundamentals have changed suddenly enough, so that leaves 0-1% as the proximate best chance.

Growth and inflation are broadly linked in general and in the Eurozone. The only time inflation has dipped below 0 in the last quarter century was in 2014, when energy prices dropped precipitously. This was accompanied by a 5% drop in year-on-year output. FT reports that economic malaise in the Eurozone is starting to lift (https://www.ft.com/content/8ffb5d91-074b-4fd2-8b74-bfbbb60750e7), with growth slowing but output still higher than last year. For the past 4-5 years, Euro inflation has sat comfortably between 1 and 2%, and has only this month dropped below 1. So I'd say it's about even odds that it'll sit on either side of 1, with a slight boost for above, given reversion to the mean and the FT's apparent evidence of improved economic prospects.

Great FT article on what to expect from inflation figures that will be coming out over the next few months: https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2020/04/27/1587998585000/Inflation-figures-are-about-to-get-fuzzier/ If it's paywalled for you, the key takeaways are the following:
1) Energy accounts for ~10% of the inflation basket in the Eurozone, which is quite a significant share of inflation. Since oil prices have fallen off a cliff, expect this to dampen inflation figures.
2) The inflation basket itself has changed markedly as a result of the pandemic — clearly, consumption patterns have changed (gloves and masks are a much bigger piece of the *actual* basket now, for instance!). But Eurostat  has said that it will keep its inflation basket unchanged until 2021.
3) Eurostat is still tracking travel/tourism-related services and flights that are still available, at least on paper. But in reality, these services and flights often are not occurring at all! So, expect a lot of noise in the inflation data over the next few months. But overall, the picture seems to be subdued inflation figures (whether this reflects reality is another question).

Edging closer to 0.1-1.0% bracket due moreso to the way that Eurostat builds the inflation index. I would guess that monetary policy would flex to avoid "on paper" deflation, so low weighting here. (Lots of the info here comes from FTs Alphaville segment) Pro falling inflation:
Major fall in fuel prices which are a significant proportion of inflation calculation spend. This is filtering through at the moment and is likely to continue to impact in June.
Eurostat is not changing the makeup of its inflation basket this year, which will keep lots of items that are not being used (such as petrol, flights, etc) and are likely to be falling in price, while not increasing the share lots of the "new normal" items (cleaning products, loo roll, etc) which would contribute to inflationary growth.
Equally inflation measures don't price in the decrease in "deals" provided by major retailers which would have the effect of artificially increasing prices.
General demand shock - despite some support to consumers (e.g. furlough scheme), it is clear that demand for lots of items that comprise the basket of goods has dropped off. Pro rising inflation:
Damage to global supply chains for lots of products creating supply shortfalls.
Monetary policy in the form of cut IRs and QE larger than many expected.

The annual inflation for the Eurozone has bounced between 0.7 and 1.7% over the last year [1]. March 2020, which is the first with COVID impacts was at 0.7%, same as last October, with the big deflation in energy from the Feb numbers [1].  Inflation has not been above 2%, and since food prices are likely to increase due to demand from continued effects from COVID, a total deflationary number seems unlikely. It seems like it will depend on what happens with oil. If oil continues to see little-to-no inflation (or continued deflation), then the lower value seems more likely. If it does increase, then the higher value seems possible. [1] https://tradingeconomics.com/euro-area/inflation-cpi

Economic contraction due to Covid will likely result in price drops across many sectors, especially travel, automotive and energy.  This will result in littoe to no inflation, or perhaps even deflation.
Further adjusting down due to energy prices in freefall.

During COVID the correct measure of HICP can never be concise. However, according to Eurostat the inflation rate for march20 was at 0.7%. Even though prices for food may have been up already, the sharp losses of oil price could lead to a further dampening of inflation in the coming months. As the economy will stay under pressure for the foreseeing time, the demand for oil will stay low. With almost 10% weighting of energy in the HICP, oil, gas etc. can offset even further rising food prices eventually.
Struggle to see it being significantly higher than March's 0.7%.  Will revisit after April's number is published
Suspect it will be negative inflation over all but high inflation ok some items I e. Food could keep it positive overall
March was 0.7. No reason to believe that it will be higher in June.

A brief review of 5-year historical indicates inflation never reaching 2% - even with the ECB pursuing a negative interest rate policy. 
Qualitatively speaking - modest inflation infers "slack" in the economy - where neither wages nor goods are increasing in price. And that seems to be the case for Main Street EU.
Inflation can also come from relative currency pairs losing value and faith of the marketplace - however, euro is near to being a reserve currency - as such -  measuring relative strength to other major world currencies  - EUR:USD and EUR:GBP, over the past 3 years, seems to have traveled in a defined sideways pattern - no reason to expect a breakout either way in 2020.
In contrast to the Argentina peso:USD or :EUR - where the charts reflect a steady erosion in currency value relative to the base currency, and where Main Street wage and price inflation is severe.

Eurozone inflation since 1997 has generally been relatively stable (i.e. one year tends to follow the previous) with clear exceptions, e.g. the financial crash in 2008, where inflation first increased highly and then fell quickly.  The past three years (2016 - 2019) have seen eurozone inflation between 1% and 2%, and hence this is my main prediction. However, there is potential for a financial crash, which I'd expect to result in a large increase in eurozone inflation (as per 2008 or 2000), or there could be efforts by the eurozone to reduce inflation (as between 2014 and 2016 for example, when it hovered between 0% and 0.5%. I feel intuitively that these possibilities are equally likely, hence them both having the same percentages, but are also relatively unlikely, hence both having low percentages. The 1% chance for "0% or less" is because there is clearly this possibilities, but it seems intuitively remote and previous precedence would back up that intuition. I would also say that the June average tens to be at or around the average of Jan-May, hence I would look again at the numbers at June. This would also affect the chances of the 0-1% or >2% options, as, if a crash for example hasn't happened by the end of May, it is clearly less likely to happen by the end of June, as it is likely to happen by the end of June when judged from today, at the start of January. This also fits in with the ECB's desire to keep the eurozone inflation "below, but close to, 2%".

I used EU inflation rate data to predict June 2020's annual inflation rate with a forecasting algorithm (FB Prophet). If no major events happen that could affect consumer confidence, then we could predict with current inflation rate trends that inflation should be close to 1%. I'm favouring 0.1%-1% because my algorithm predicts 0.9%. However, considering that this is so close to 1%, I can't say much on its accuracy. I would keep my eye out on European consumer behavior, particularly if there's news on changes in the European energy, food, industrial or services sector as proxies to adjust my predictions accordingly.

Historical eurozone inflation rates only slightly weighted towards the last few years. I think @ajr1000 's approach to the base rate here https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/937713 makes sense - as a minor modification I use data from Jan 2009 onwards, which gives 11, 32, 32, 25 for the answer options. The inflation rate seems to be on a downward trend for the last few months, and given the timeframe of the question I think at this stage it is reasonable to assume that this trend will continue. Measures that could be used by the ECB to bring inflation closer to their target value of close to 2% such as more negative interest rates or more asset purchasing programs seem to become less and less popular with both the public and the committee members at the ECB. In addition it seems that these tools don't have the effect on inflation they used to have, requiring some adjustment of the narrative or a change of approach altogether. I therefore increase the probability of the second lowest bucket from the base rate at the expense of higher inflation buckets.
